Messages.Author: Hinrich Christian Rahlfs
Messages.Content: This week's lab is a do-it-yourself lab to get to know MeVisLab. Learn where to download the software and get started with the basics. While no submission is necessary this week, try to tackle as many tasks as you can, as we'll only briefly review the lab next week. Don't hesitate to reach out with any questions on the helpdesk forum. Our first in-person lab session will be on April 25th.

Messages.Author: Sebastian Kralik
Messages.Content: Hi, Is there a way to read PixelSpacing/SpacingBetweenSlices directly in a PythonArithmetic Panel (without loading the file once more with pydicom)?

Messages.Author: Hinrich Christian Rahlfs
Messages.Content: Hi, you can access it using the Info module.  ctx.field("Info.voxelSizeX").value

Messages.Author: Cederic Aßmann
Messages.Content: Dear all, Does anybody get good results for the blob detection algorithm? I was wondering by just implementing the formula: result[u, t, c, z, y, x] = sigma**2 * np.linalg.det(hessian) and changing the sigma from sigma = 1 to e.g. sigma = 35, the change highlights an inverse mask of the tumor.  I thought the tumor should be filled with the SoView2DOverlay module. Regarding the task .pdf it means that in the tumor region the det(hessian) is small -> no intensity peaks. Makes sense, but how to detect desired blobs? Has anybody the same problem? Can somebody give me a hint on that? Or is that the desired outcome? Thank you! Cederic Aßmann

Messages.Author: Yann Lucien Michel Lerquemain
Messages.Content: I have the same issue. I also tried with a threshold on the eigenvalues of the Hessian Matrix instead of its determinant, to no avail. However, the eyes are detected very nicely (as they should).

Messages.Author: Hinrich Christian Rahlfs
Messages.Content: Hi,  There are multiple parts to the answer.  1. The size of the detected blobs needs to be changed in the module gaussHessian. (This is the module calculating the Hessian. The sigma in the RunPythonScript only scales the result).  2. A blob with an intensity maximum leads to negative eigenvalues => negative determinant. This is why you have a positive determinant at the eyes (dark blob) but a negative determinant at the tumor (light blob). You can try calculating the absolute value of the determinant or by multiplying by -1.  3. As you already see, blob detection is not the best method for tumor segmentation. You will hear about different methods in today's lecture.   For the submission, an implementation of blob detection is fine. You will not need to find the perfect sigma to get the maximum number of points.

What are current state-of-the-art techniques for pretty 3D medical image visualisation. I hope that I stated my question/suggestion understandable and hope that you could provide some information on that. Thank you Cederic

Discussions.Discussion_Name: RescaleSlope und RescaleIntercept missing in DICOM file 'Brain_Gliomatosis_T2-TIRM.dcm'

Messages.Author: Cederic Aßmann
Messages.Content: Dear Mr. Rahlfs,  I was wondering about the missing tags of RescaleSlope and RescaleIntercept in the above named Dicom file. Could you please explain, why those tags are missing in this type of medical image data? Thank you and best regards! Cederic Aßmann

Messages.Author: Hinrich Christian Rahlfs
Messages.Content: It is correct that the two are missing in this data set. This is because it is a T2-weighted MRI scan. RescaleIntercept/Slope are used to convert the voxel values into a unit. However, a T2-weighted MRI scan is not a quantitative measurement and therefore cannot/does not need to be converted into a unit.  The situation is different for CT scans, for example. CT scans are quantitaive and are mesured in Hounsfield Units.
